channel.title: video on The B0ardside
channel.description: Recent content in video on The B0ardside

item.title: Cindy and China live performances
Kei Terauchi - Outer Sunset Mix 2021
item.description: Recordings from Kei Terauchi to accompany her piece ‘What Makes The World Go Around - Outer Sunset Mix 2021’ in The B0ardside zine issue #2. Your browser does not support the video tag. Your browser does not support the video tag. Your browser does not support the video tag. Your browser does not support the video tag.

item.title: Let's Talk About The Sunset
item.description: Awesome wee vid of my neighborhood!

item.title: Brent Willson - Lost City and Bridge Bardo
item.description: Finally edited the video footage from our last art show, Brent Willson’s Lost City and Bridge Bardo!

item.title: Wildfire Skies
item.description: The sky above the port was the color of … Wed, September 9, 2020, San Francisco. The sky above the Bay Area was filled with orange ash and smoke which came from the Bear Fire burning near Oroville, 150 miles northeast of San Francisco. Music by TVO - “Sketch 3 - Hydroacoustics” from https://t-v-o.bandcamp.com/album/distant-lights-receding

item.title: The B0ardside in The Million Dollar Mailbox
item.description: Ah, super lovely review of My Side Of The City and The B0ardside #1 from my buddy Dan Shahin .. This is taken from a longer livestream here. thanks Dan!

item.title: Kei Terauchi - Tempest in Light
item.description: This is a recording of Kei Terauchi’s composition she contributed to the first issue of the B0arside zine: Your browser does not support the video tag. The text which accompanies it: This piece portrays an experience one might have wandering the Outer Sunset neighborhood from dusk till dawn. The story is extremely simple. It’s nightfall. The protagonist walks and revels in the moonlight and music until the sun rises.

item.title: The Art Of Code - Dylan Beattie
item.description: Super entertaining talk from Dylan Beattie, encompassing history of computational arts, live coding, math and having fun!

item.title: Further_in live stream
item.description: This was my live set from Further_in a few weeks back - Had a list minute thought to stick on my Thor costume!

item.title: Phil Burk - Porting the Hierarchical Music Specification Language (HMSL) to JUCE
item.description: I was out in London for 10 days recently, where I attended the JUCE Audio Developers Conference. Some great talks! I particularly enjoyed this one by Phil Burk on HMSL - Hierarchical Music Specification Language - a language he was involved in designing a Mill College, here in the Bay Area from the mid eighties till the early nineties. I’ve asked Phil to present a simlilar talk at Algorithmic Art Assembly 2020, which he’s agreed to!

item.title: Oboe - low latency Android Audio
item.description: I’ve started building a toy Granular Synth for Android, using this Oboe library. This video is a great introduction to it..

item.title: videos from Algorithmic Art Assembly
item.description: Oh, should have posted this a while back! All videos from the Algorithmic Art Assembly conference/festival I ran in March, are now online – Friday Day Friday Night Saturday Day Saturday Night

item.title: Let's Lisp Like It's 1959
item.description: Nicely delivered talk by Kristoffer Gronlund about the origins of the LISP language..

item.title: The Golden Rules of Audio Programming, according to Pete Goodliffe
item.description: I’ve been dealing with threaded data access race conditions between my ui and audio thread this weekend, so found this talk pretty informative – !

item.title: Luke Fowler and Mark Fell: Computers and Cooperative Music-Making
item.description: Wow, this is great, found this while looking up Mark Fell videos - an exhibition he curated with Luke Fowler, documenting two early computer music languages The Composers Desktop Project (CDP) and Hierarchical Musical Specification Language (HMSL).

item.title: Joscha Bach - The Ghost in the Machine
item.description: From this year’s Chaos Computer Club, a great talk from a series, ' From Computation to Consciousness', by Joscha Bach –

item.title: Ron Pressler 'Finite of sense & infinite of thought'
item.description: Found this on hacker news over Christmas - super good talk by Ron Pressler, spinning an awesome narrative around history of computation, logic and algebra –

item.title: David Schmüdde - Aesthetics and Narrative: Programming What Cannot Be Programmed
item.description: Great talk on composing functions for creative use!

item.title: Sheffield Algorave 2018
item.description: Just got back from the very awesome Livecode Festival #2 in Sheffield UK, a gathering of like minded music programmers and algorithmic artists - super inspiring! Here’s a screencast i captured of my set for the Algorave:

item.title: The Tragedy of systemd
item.description: Awesome talk from BSDCan 2018, a balanced look at systemd’s history and ideas..

item.title: BCPL Algos 1 & 2
item.description: Here’s a couple of new tracks I’ve put together using my Soundb0ard software..

item.title: Procedural Programming: It's Back? It Never Went Away
item.description: I found this next video on a great Hacker News thread, “What is your favourite tech talk?"

item.title: Soundb0ard in use at Algosix
item.description: I’ve had my head down doing a bunch of work on my Soundb0ard software, in prep for playing at Algosix last weekend. The festival was awesome, so much great live music! I was quite happy with my performance, give it a listen/view:

item.title: Dalriada - scottish skate video by Iron Giraffe
item.description: Check this awesome new skate video out of Scotland - great stuff! Even a wee shot of Toby Patterson in there! DALRIADA from Iron Giraffe on Vimeo.

item.title: Steve DiPaola at Dorkbot, SF, 2018
item.description: I ended up missing this recent Dorkbot night, so glad to see the talk turning up online - this is great! Steve DiPaola, Computational/Cognitive Modelling of Expression & Creativity, Dorkbot-SF, 2018-01-31 from pronoiac on Vimeo.

item.title: TidalCycles Tutorials
item.description: Alex McLean’s TidalCycles has been a big influence on my own Soundb0ard, and lately, now that my instruments are mostly built, I’ve been looking for ways to algorithmically modify them more. This series of howto’s by Mike Hodnick/Kindohm have been an amazing source of inspiration - super clear and very entertaining - here’s the first episode:

item.title: Jason Turner - Rich Code For Tiny Computers
item.description: JD from work turned me on to this awesome CppCon talk by Jason Turner - in it he builds a simple commodore64 game using modern C++17 features, and an astounding role for Matt Godbolt’s (what a name!) Compiler Explorer

item.title: Bureau For The Containment Of Programmatic Lifeforms
item.description: I’m just back from a two week holiday in the UK, and while over there, I took part in the first Energized Labs meetup (thanks Matt!), and gave a talk about my efforts in trying to combine my art and tech influences.. Also check both Matt and Martin’s talks from the same session ..

item.title: Cubase64
item.description: This is nuts, some guy wrote an awesome sound editor for the Commodore 64, Cubase64! Link comes via man like Tack

item.title: An Intuitive Understanding of the Fourier Transform
item.description: Really nicely, and visually, explained introduction to the Fast Fourier Transform - great stuff!

item.title: Making Music and Art Through Machine Learning
item.description: This is a good chat with Doug Eck, of the Google Magenta project It’s a project I’ve been keeping an eye on, as it has a ton of potential. I’ve generated some melodies based on their Melody RNN - although i need to spend more time with it, as I’ve been more focussed on own generative algorithms.

item.title: Robert Henke Granulator
item.description: Hmm, my granular synth hasn’t quite come together yet, but I’m learning a load. This is a pretty informative (promo) video from Robert Henke/Monolake showcasing his ‘Granulator’ plugin for Ableton Live. If i can get mine to sound anything like that i’ll be stoked!

item.title: Curtis Roads, Microsound
item.description: I’ve just read ‘Microsound’ by Curtis Roads. I was well aware of the microsound movement, but hadn’t realized the depth of the theory behind granular synthesis, with it’s history going back to the 1940s, and early practise from Xenakis (using tapes) and this lad, Curtis Roads, programming his own granular synth on a PDP-11/20 in 1974 - what a bad-ass! Check this site for some good background and papers. I found these videos of Curtis Roads, via the site linked above.

item.title: John Hughes - Why Functional Programming Matters
item.description: This is a great talk - loved the speaker’s mannerisms and humor!

item.title: Palmbomen II - Memories of Cindy
item.description: Have you been watching season 3 of Twin Peaks? so fscking good! This is kinda up there – Memories Of Cindy Pt. 1 Memories Of Cindy Pt. 2 Looking forward to receiving the second volume in the mail. Grab a copy

item.title: Jenn Schiffer talks
item.description: Up at XOXO last year, the Jenn Schiffer talk was definitely one of the most fun: this older one i found from 2015 is equally as entertaining, I love the opening sequence, it’s got a kind of “cool” Portlandia vibe!

item.title: Let Vim do the typing
item.description: Discovered lots of great vim talks - this one is neat:

item.title: Developers Writing The Future
item.description: I just read this pretty awesome book ‘I Hate The Internet’ by Jarett Kobek. It has a nice cynical irreverence, but very astute awareness of the power of modern social networks. Coincidentally, I just came across this decent talk from Joel Spolsky, which if you kinda squint a little, sorta touches upon a few similar subjects as in ‘I Hate The Internet’, at least in that there a lot of assumptions and decisions baked into the algorithms in modern software, a lot of hidden power structures and bias.

item.title: Runtime Scheduling, Strange Loop 2016
item.description: Super nice low level details of scheduling, from kernel scheduling to user space scheduling, with contrasting demo implementations in Go and Erlang..

item.title: Graham Dunning, Mechanical Techno
item.description: I was reading up on ALGOMECH 2016, “the first festival of algorithmic and mechanical movement” - which looks ace! This video, by one of the performers, Graham Dunning, is kinda mind blowing - pay off around the 3:38 mark:

item.title: Julia Evans, Strange Loop 2016
item.description: Fun talk from Julia Evans, from this year’s Strange Loop conference:

item.title: Plainview Public Access
item.description: This is a crazy awesome animation by Anthony Lombardo and John Chrostek – “It is one-o-clock in the morning. You’ve had a long and tiresome day, and despite your best intentions, dozed off far before you meant to. Asleep in the embrace of your old blue La-Z-Boy, you feel a flicker like a breeze full of static at room temperature. You awaken. The television is still on. Your eyes adjust.

item.title: Daniel Schiffman - Purple Rain in Processing
item.description: I was listening to the Creative Coding podcast with Daniel Shiffman the other day - One thing they discussed was Daniel’s new Coding Challenges youtube series - this one to do a ‘Purple Rain’ in Processing is really fun!

item.title: The Silicon Valley of Hardware
item.description: Really great wee short from Wired.com about how Shenzhen became the powerhouse it is now..

item.title: Rob Landley on Toybox
item.description: Ah, this is ace!

item.title: Android - High Performance Audio
item.description: I’m currently working on a Brillo audio component, which will require very low latency performance. While searching for some tips and prior art, I came across this talk from Google I/O 2013. A bit older now, but provides an excellent overview of the problem domain and approaches to solving those issues..

item.title: The Computer Chronicles: Unix (1985)
item.description: Awesome episode of the Computer Chronicles, this one focussed on Unix. Gary Killdall is a don!

item.title: Efficiency with Algorithms, Performance with Data Structures
item.description: This is a pretty entertaining talk from Chandler Carruth at CppCon 2014 - lots of good takeaways..

item.title: SF - Streets by VICE
item.description: Pretty decent wee documentary on the changing face of SF from VICE mag. Near the beginning a lot of the location shots don’t match the narrative, but the interview with Andre Nickatina makes it totally worthwhile!

item.title: Bryan Cantrill at Paper's We Love, NYC 2016
item.description: Bryan Cantrill on another awesome one!

item.title: 1987 - Hypercard demo
item.description: I never played with Hypercard, only ever heard about it - love this demo of it:

item.title: Uncanny Valley
item.description: Awesome wee sci-fi short..

item.title: History and Spirit of C and C++
item.description: Some excellent bits of BCPL history in here, which I hadn’t come across before… History and Spirit of C and C++ - Olve Maudal from NDC Conferences on Vimeo.

item.title: Embedded Android Overview
item.description: Amazingly smooth presentation under time pressure from Karim Yaghmour, giving a super fast overview of the content in his Embedded Android book. I’ve been deep in Android source code these past few weeks - I just moved from an Ops role to Embedded Developer - I’ve never read or written so much C code in my life - it’s awesome!

item.title: Sophie Wilson, ARM ISA Architect
item.description: Sophie Wilson is a boss..

item.title: Skateboarding in Pine Ridge
item.description: Really great use of skateboarding to help build a sense of community for youth on a native american reservation.. Oh, also, super good soundtrack featuring David Pajo! As pretty much all my skate videos are, found via the awesome The Walloper.

item.title: Libmill on Randal Schwartz's FLOSS Weekly show
item.description: I’m moving into a new job position soon involving way more code, working in C/C++. I’ve just started watching this podcast series and it’s excellent - this one in particular is super relevant, bringing one of the best features from Golang into C. I like the minimalism of the project, it seems very much in alignment with the philosophy behind Suckless. (There’s a previous episode, speaking with Anselm R Garbe from suckless, i’d also highly recommend.

item.title: How To Build a Skyscraper
item.description: Pretty rad skyscraper history as software-engineering-metaphor..

item.title: Andrew Gerrand talking at Go UK 2015 - stupid gopher tricks
item.description: Hah, some awesome bits in here…

item.title: Grant Taylor, skateboard shit
item.description: Absolutely sick skate video, fscking nuts! found via The Walloper

item.title: Visualising Program Execution
item.description: Super fun live demo of program tracing and visualisation from this years Strange Loop conf..

item.title: From Solaris to Illumos
item.description: Bryan Cantrill, as entertaining as always..

item.title: MOS 6502 microcontroller
item.description: Nice and short 30 min talk about the origins and background to the MOS Technologies 6502 micro-controller, which came out in 1975 and powered the BBC Micro, the Commodore 64, first Nintendo, amongst many others. Super good!

item.title: FORTRAN!
item.description: Oh shit! this is incredible - IBM engineer walks through the development of a FORTRAN program, including I’m guessing, the first appearance of a GOTO statement! Then, in part two, they have their FORmula TRANslator translate a Fortran program into IBM symbolic language/assembly, and output it to PUNCH CARDS!!. wow..

item.title: Shit Present - Kick Me
item.description: Awesome video for awesome track! Found via Ben’s blog

item.title: Skater Dater, 1965
item.description: the best short film ever? Nominate it for the National Film Registry

item.title: Perl and Portaudio
item.description: Super nice demo of algorithmic sound generation with Perl and Portaudio… from here

item.title: Brian Kernighan speaking with Computerphile
item.description: The legendary Brian Kernighan speaking to Computerphile about early days of computing. SHort and sweet video..

item.title: Hashicorp are Insane(ly great)
item.description: Oh man, this talk is nuts - Mitchell Hashimoto introducing Terraform and Consul together..

item.title: Selection of Early British Computers
item.description: I just finished reading Early British Computers by Simon Lavington - super good! There’s an awesome playlist of videos which feature the computers covered. Here’s a selection..

item.title: Roots of Computing, 1963
item.description: Oh man, this is incredible, seriously best historic piece I’ve watched, with the origins of operating system methodoligies, and crazy typewriter I/O UX, pre-CRTs!

item.title: Docker Storage Drivers
item.description: Super nice quick overview of the importance of Copy-On-Write filesystems to Docker, going into detail of the benefits and downsides to each of the CoW options - AuFS, BTRFS, ZFS, Overlayfs, Device Mapper - great stuff!

item.title: From Config Management to a proper Scheduling system
item.description: This was the excellent closing talk to the recent CoreOS Fest, Kelsey Hightower walks through differing approaches to deployment, from configuration management to container scheduling, via Kubernetes..

item.title: Craig Silverstein on the origin of Google
item.description: I only just learned about this guy Craig Silverstein, who was Google employee #3 after Larry and Sergey. There’s a ton more info about him if you go searching, but this is an ace little 10 minute video where he talks about the origins of google..

item.title: Vint Cerf, history of packets
item.description: Me and tack went to see the illustrious Vint Cerf speak during the week - he was awesome! Here’s an excellent youtube interview with him, on the history of packets:

item.title: Systems At Facebook Scale
item.description: Wow, this is one of the most practical, technical talks I’ve seen in a while - super good!

item.title: Weaponizing Your Pets
item.description: My wife and I got a new projector recently (this one), so I had some nerds round to watch some tech talks. My friend Jerome turned us on to this one, super fun!

item.title: NetBSD: Not A Linux Distro
item.description: Great intro to FreeBSD from George Neville-Neil presenting history and current status..

item.title: boston dynamics
item.description: dang!! Boston Dynamics four legged robots are amazeballs:

item.title: Etcd 2.0 walkthrough
item.description: Excellent overview of Etcd and description of new features / bug fixes in 2.0..

item.title: Tony Hoare on the universals of computation
item.description: I’m currently reading Tony Hoare’s Communicating Sequential Processes - it’s awesome! I searched to see if I could find some youtube videos of him - this one is brilliant, him talking about what should be taught in Computer Science, the universal ideas of logic and geometry unpinning computation, going back to Euclid and Artistotle. Great stuff!

item.title: User Space Networking
item.description: One theme I’ve noticed recently is a move to User Space networking - not for normal application use per se, but for specific high throughput cases, where the kernel’s general network stack’s overhead is too much. This isn’t a new thing, but something I’ve never gotten around to exploring. This vid, from last year, provides an overview of three different implementations..

item.title: How To Debug Anything
item.description: Pretty decent talk on debugging methodology..

item.title: Greyglers!
item.description: Vint Cerf,the Don..

item.title: How to Build a Mind
item.description: Hugely compelling talk by Joscha Bach covering history and possible futures of AI.. Found here

item.title: You Can Be A Kernel Hacker
item.description: Brilliant, brilliant talk from Julia Evans, getting excited about kernel hacking. Warning: Super infectious levels of enthusiasm!

item.title: K&R
item.description: Sad circumstance, lovely stories…

item.description: Beautifully shot, mind blowing short documentary about New York’s early telecoms buildings, the Western Union Building and the AT&T Long Lines Building .. Found via BldBlog site

item.title: Eric Brewer on Container usage at Google
item.description: Eric Brewer’s keynote from Dockercon14 - Crazy stuff, definitely feels like Containers have gained mass momentum, and we’re about to undergo a major shift in Systems Architecture. Very exciting times!

item.title: Seymour Cray profile
item.description: This 80’s three part piece on Seymour Cray is pretty ace - especially the Lou Reed R.A.D. (Rock Against Drugs!) and Greenpeace ad’s at about 11m12s in!

item.title: Solomon Hykes, Dockercon14
item.description: Solomon Hykes, creator of Docker, speaking at Dockercon - paints a nicely detailed overview of all the new Docker ecosystem libraries released recently - Libcontainer, Libchan, and Libswarm - basically all middle layer abstractions which seem to have buy across all the main platforms and providers. He starts talking about 10mins in..

item.description: Excellent interview on Linux Action Show with Brandon Philips, lots of great info on understanding and running CoreOS ::

item.description: Yow! this is great! I know my Unix history pretty well, but Multics - aside from knowing it was the precursor to Unix, i didn’t know much else of the details or who was involved - WATCH THIS! NOW! :D

item.title: Frank Quitely - Geek Hard
item.description: My mother, over in Glasgow, was telling me about a BBC program called A Day In The Life, and specifically of an episode about Frank QUitely - i found it on youtube.com for about 30 mins but it’s already been taken down. (I didn’t get to see it either!!). Fortunately however, I did find this lovely interview with “Frank” (whose name i just found out is a stage name! )

item.description: Love this new video for Tense Men - It’s all shot around Stoke Newington in London, super close to Pat’s old house.

item.description: Sadly, Jim Weirich, creator of the Ruby Rake tool died a few days back. Here is a great talk he delivered, explaining the concept and an implementation of an applicative Y Combinator:

item.description: Watched this on wednesday - crazy how dated it all seems now, and well, it is! Dang!

item.description: more future arrivals now.. Read more here

item.title: Better Vim With Damian Conway
item.description: Get yer Vim freak on with Damian Conway! Super fun talk..

item.description: Tom Dale, author of Ember.js talking about the symmetry between MVC and restful routes.. // found via https://twitter.com/littlecalculist/status/418800989634695168

item.title: Go Presentation
item.description: More and more I’ve been dabbling with Go, which, mainly due to Hacker News, i’ve been reading so many good things about. The syntax is super easy to pick up, but the killer feature seems to be the concurrency primitives - the Go Functions and message passing Channels seem like a super tight, rock solid implementation of Hoare’s Communicating Sequential Processes. The following video is a really succinct walk through of building a concurent multi-protocol chat application ala Chat Roulette.

item.title: Troubleshooting the JVM at Twitter
item.description: This talk is incredibly informative - Twitter have their own fork of OpenJDK, in which they have enabled registers on the CPU, normally used by the Java Compiler - this enables Frame Pointers which perf can read and translate, enabling a full Stack trace from JVM bytecode right down into the kernel. Beyond simply CPU counters and stack trace, they also tie in other JVM flags which export DTrace counters, and use these to construct connections between memory allocation and the running process, so in the end you have a tool which can spans JVM -> kernel connections, alongside CPU -> memory.

item.title: The B0ardside Top 13 records 2013
item.description: Was hard to cut two out from this selection, so here’s my top 12 for the past year, as usual a bit of a mix between the rock n roll and the electronic noise.. item.title: Berkshelf - the missing piece
item.description: If you've been following my past few posts, you've seen i was investigating how best to integrate the plethora of Chef testing tools that've been coming out — foodcritic, chefspec, test-kitchen, mini-test — and although not testing tools per se, Berkshelf and Vagrant are the other pieces of the puzzle… but how to fit them all together? What is the directory structure for keeping your Berkfile - at the top of the repo?

item.title: JVM and GC Performance Tuning
item.description: Been working a lot of JVM GC performance problems of late, so this video interview my friend Johan turned me on has some great info -Attila Szegedi on JVM and GC Performance Tuning at Twitter. http://www.infoq.com/interviews/szegedi-performance-tuning

item.title: Usenix/Lisa 12
item.description: Just got back from the Usenix/Lisa 12 conference in San Diego, and had a great time, super inspiring talks and content. Highlight of the conference for me was Brendan Gregg speaking on Performance Analysis Methodologies - most of his talk was based upon a paper he just published in ACM - Thinking Methodically About Performance. The talks haven't yet been published on the Usenix website, but Brendan's blog has a ton of great looking content and older talks including this one on Visualisations for Performance Analysis

item.title: Food Fight Show on Chef Cookbook Best Practises
item.description: this google+ hangout, combined with this post and all it's links, provides plenty of good discussion and ideas for Chef.

item.title: Don't use nosql
item.description: enjoyed this talk by Mathias Meyer :

item.title: Percona Table Checksum
item.description: I must admit MySQL replication is something I've never felt too comfortable with - in most of my positions, I've had the luxury of working with a full time DBA who would handle all database related work. In my current workplace we have three major pairs of database machines, and have been going through upgrading them all to Percona MySQL 5.5. As you'd expect data integrity is of the highest importance, so discovering this Percona Table Checksum tool is a real life saver, providing an amazing tool for verifying and fixing any drift or problems with MySQL slaves.

item.title: (short) history of DevOps
item.description:

item.title: webkit and chrome internals
item.description: I went along to the SF Web Performance Meetup last night, for a talk by Ilya Grigorik which was one of the best and most informative Meetups I've been along to - lots of meaty details on how Webkit in general works, and specifically how Chrome uses it across the many platforms it runs on. The video has just been posted here - Video streaming by Ustream Ilya starts speaking around the 12 minute mark.

item.title: Leap Motion
item.description: ooh, nice. Just saw this company mentioned in the comments of an HN thread.

item.title: some fav Velocity talks
item.description: Velocity was on last week, and I was following along enviously on twitter - I'm making a promise to myself that I'll be along in person next year! Quite a few of the talks now appearing online - here's a couple I've watched so far..

item.title: Von Neumann and the Institute For Advanced Study
item.description: I've started reading George Dyson's “Turing's Cathedral”, and really enjoying it - I love reading the historical context of technological progress, feels like a lot of sociological reading, filling in another of the endless jigsaw pieces of a larger all-encompassing narrative. Here's George Dyson doing a lecture on the material in the book :

item.title: Backblaze
item.description: the legendary Mike Hoover turned me on to Backblaze a few months back - they're a cloud storage provider, who opened up the design for their chassis and storage pod solution so you can build your own “Storage Pod 2.0: a 135-terabyte, 4U server for $7,384″ (blog post here)

item.title: Technology As Society's Engine
item.description: Unfortunately I forget where I found this link - Hacker News? The Edge Newsletter? I dunno, but it's a pretty interesting one - A debate between an MIT professor, Erik Brynjolfsson, and an Economist, Tyler Cowen, about the the role of technology in driving economic growth. My views side with the MIT professor, as does most of the audience in the debate. I won't repeat any of the arguments made in the debate, but what I will add is that the unequal distribution of wealth we see around today is not a symptom of lack of technological growth, it is purely down to good old fashioned political manipulation and deep rooted traditions of cronyism, a tradition thousands of years old.

item.title: JVM tuning for VMs
item.description:
This is an excellent talk about the interaction between the various layers of memory abstraction from the a machine's physical memory down through the Hypervisor's view, to the Guest OS's and down into the JVM:
// found via Marakana //

item.title: Claude Shannon and the Clams
item.description: I finished reading James Gleick's The Information tonite - so good! Really, the central character is Claude Shannon, who I'm ashamed to admit I didn't previously know much about. Had a quick search when i finished it and found this decent little 30 min documentary which gives a good overview -

item.title: The Information
item.description: I started reading James Gleick's “The Information” last week and haven't been able to put it down yet - so good! I just found this video of a talk he presented at Google last year on the book, looks ace, i'll save it for watching this evening.

item.title: NeXT documentary
item.description: Bookmarked this video via Boing Boing last week, but only got round to watching it tonite - pretty interesting little 20 minute documentary series called “Entrepreneurs” doing an episode on Steve Jobs and NeXT back in 1985

item.title: Bring the Noyce
item.description: yow, sorry, that title's a really bad pun! So two things here - i started to watch this video with Robert Noyce talking about the development of the IC, but in the introduction and in his opening, they talk about an article written by Tom Wolfe about Noyce - now, Tom Wolfe was a massive influence on my teenage self, or at least one of his books, The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test, which a friends older brother passed on to me when i was fifteen.

item.title: real-time stats >
item.description: Found this Facebook engineering video quite fascinating, a nicely detailed platform overview of FB's new real-time analytics system: Watch live streaming video from facebookeducation at livestream.comIn the comment section, someone posted a link to a somewhat similar presentation from Twitter about their real-time solution:: Rainbird: Realtime Analytics at Twitter (Strata 2011) View more presentations from Kevin Weil (hello Johan!)

item.title: secret military history of Silicon Valley
item.description: This video ties in so well with a lot of other recent histories - from Adam Curtis' “All Watched Over By Machines Of Loving Grave” to the Ken Holling's book I'm in the middle of reading - “Welcome To Mars”. Video found via Boing Boing
